problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which of the following is a derived unit?
problems.hint: It's the SI unit of force.
problems.detailed: A Newton is a derived unit defined as \( \text{kg} \cdot \text{m/s}^2 \), while kilogram, second, and ampere are fundamental SI units.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which quantity has the SI unit of \( \text{kg} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{s}^2 \)?
problems.detailed: Energy has the unit of joules, which is equivalent to \( \text{kg} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{s}^2 \).

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: What is the SI base unit of electric current?
problems.hint: It's one of the seven fundamental SI units.
problems.detailed: The ampere (A) is the SI base unit for electric current.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Given the equation \( \text{F = ma} \), what is the SI unit of force?
problems.hint: Multiply the unit of mass with that of acceleration.
problems.detailed: Force is mass (kg) times acceleration (\(\text{m/s}^2\)), giving \( \text{kg} \cdot \text{m/s}^2 \), which is a Newton (N).

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: In the equation for pressure \( \text{P} = \text{F/A} \), what is the unit of pressure?
problems.detailed: Force is \( \text{kg} \cdot \text{m/s}^2 \), area is \( \text{m}^2 \), so pressure is \( \text{kg/m} \cdot \text{s}^2 \), known as a pascal (Pa).

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Given the equation \( \text{T} = 2\pi \sqrt{\text{L/g}} \), what is the unit of \( \text{g} \)?
problems.hint: Make the RHS dimensionless under the square root.
problems.detailed: For the square root to be unitless, \( \text{L/g} \) must be in \( \text{s}^2 \), so \( \text{g} \) must be in \( \text{m/s}^2 \).

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: An equation for power is given as \( \text{P} = \text{k} \cdot \text{A}^3 \cdot \text{T} \), where \( \text{P} \) has units of watts, \( \text{A} \) is area in \( \text{m}^2 \), and \( \text{T} \) is time in seconds. What is the unit of \( \text{k} \)?
